shloka:
सञ्जय उवाच |
तं तथा कृपयाविष्टमश्रुपूर्णाकुलेक्षणम् |
विषीदन्तमिदं वाक्यमुवाच मधुसूदनः ||२-१||
meaning_english: 2.1 Sanjaya said  To him who was thus overcome with pity and who was despondent, with eyes full of tears and agitated, Madhusudana (the destroyer of Madhu) or Krishna spoke these words.
explanation: This verse sets the stage for Krishna's teachings, highlighting Arjuna's overwhelming pity and despair as he faces the moral dilemma of war. Sanjaya describes Arjuna's emotional state, emphasizing his tearful and agitated condition. Krishna, referred to as Madhusudana, prepares to offer wisdom to guide Arjuna out of his despondency.

shloka:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |
कुतस्त्वा कश्मलमिदं विषमे समुपस्थितम् |
अनार्यजुष्टमस्वर्ग्यमकीर्तिकरमर्जुन ||२-२||
meaning_english: 2.2 The Blessed Lord said  Whence is this perilous strait come upon thee, this dejection which is unworthy of you, disgraceful, and which will close the gates of heaven upon you, O Arjuna?
explanation: Krishna begins his counsel by questioning the source of Arjuna's dejection, calling it unworthy and dishonorable for a warrior. He emphasizes that such weakness in a critical moment can lead to spiritual and worldly consequences, urging Arjuna to rise above it. This verse introduces the theme of overcoming emotional weakness through spiritual strength.

shloka:
क्लैब्यं मा स्म गमः पार्थ नैतत्त्वय्युपपद्यते |
क्षुद्रं हृदयदौर्बल्यं त्यक्त्वोत्तिष्ठ परन्तप ||२-३||
meaning_english: 2.3 Yield not to impotence, O Arjuna, son of Pritha. It does not befit thee. Cast off this mean weakness of the heart! Stand up, O scorcher of the foes!
explanation: Krishna urges Arjuna to reject weakness and rise with courage, addressing him as a formidable warrior. He calls Arjuna's despair a petty weakness of the heart, unfit for his noble character. This verse emphasizes the importance of resilience and determination in fulfilling one's duties.

shloka:
अर्जुन उवाच |
कथं भीष्ममहं सङ्ख्ये द्रोणं च मधुसूदन |
इषुभिः प्रतियोत्स्यामि पूजार्हावरिसूदन ||२-४||
meaning_english: 2.4 Arjuna said  How, O Madhusudana, shall I fight in battle with arrows against Bhishma and Drona, who are fit to be worshipped, O destroyer of enemies?
explanation: Arjuna expresses his moral conflict, questioning how he can fight against revered figures like Bhishma and Drona, whom he considers worthy of worship. His dilemma reflects the tension between personal reverence and the demands of duty. This verse highlights the emotional and ethical challenges of fulfilling one's role in difficult circumstances.

shloka:
गुरूनहत्वा हि महानुभावान्
श्रेयो भोक्तुं भैक्ष्यमपीह लोके |
हत्वार्थकामांस्तु गुरूनिहैव
भुञ्जीय भोगान् रुधिरप्रदिग्धान् ||२-५||
meaning_english: 2.5 Better it is, indeed, in this world to accept alms than to slay the most noble teachers. But if I kill them, even in this world all my enjoyments of wealth and fulfilled desires will be stained with (their) blood.
explanation: Arjuna argues that living by begging is preferable to killing his noble teachers, as the rewards of such actions would be tainted with their blood. This verse reveals his deep ethical concerns and fear of incurring sin. It underscores the struggle between worldly desires and spiritual integrity.

shloka:
न चैतद्विद्मः कतरन्नो गरीयो
यद्वा जयेम यदि वा नो जयेयुः |
यानेव हत्वा न जिजीविषामस्-
तेऽवस्थिताः प्रमुखे धार्तराष्ट्राः ||२-६||
meaning_english: 2.6 I can hardly tell which will be better, that we should conquer them or that they should conquer us. Even the sons of Dhritarashtra, after slaying whom we do not wish to live, stand facing us.
explanation: Arjuna expresses his confusion, unsure whether victory or defeat is preferable, as he dreads killing his kin, the sons of Dhritarashtra. His despair reflects the emotional weight of facing loved ones in battle. This verse captures the paralyzing uncertainty of making morally complex decisions.

shloka:
कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभावः
पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसम्मूढचेताः |
यच्छ्रेयः स्यान्निश्चितं ब्रूहि तन्मे
शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम् ||२-७||
meaning_english: 2.7 My heart is overpowered by the taint of pity; my mind is confused as to duty. I ask Thee: Tell me decisively what is good for me. I am Thy disciple. Instruct me who has taken refuge in Thee.
explanation: Arjuna, overwhelmed by pity and confused about his duty, surrenders to Krishna as his disciple, seeking clear guidance. This verse marks a pivotal moment of humility and openness to divine wisdom. It emphasizes the importance of seeking spiritual counsel in times of moral crisis.

shloka:
न हि प्रपश्यामि ममापनुद्याद्
यच्छोकमुच्छोषणमिन्द्रियाणाम् |
अवाप्य भूमावसपत्नमृद्धं
राज्यं सुराणामपि चाधिपत्यम् ||२-८||
meaning_english: 2.8 I do not see that it would remove this sorrow that burns up my senses, even if I should attain prosperous and unrivalled dominion on earth or lordship over the gods.
explanation: Arjuna laments that no worldly achievement, not even unrivaled power or divine lordship, can alleviate his deep sorrow. This verse reflects his recognition that external success cannot resolve inner turmoil. It sets the stage for Krishna’s teachings on detachment and spiritual fulfillment.

shloka:
सञ्जय उवाच |
एवमुक्त्वा हृषीकेशं गुडाकेशः परन्तप |
न योत्स्य इति गोविन्दमुक्त्वा तूष्णीं बभूव ह ||२-९||
meaning_english: 2.9 Sanjaya said  Having spoken thus to Hrishikesha (the Lord of the senses), Arjuna (the conqueror of sleep), the destroyer of foes, said to Krishna, "I will not fight" and became silent.
explanation: Arjuna, overwhelmed, declares his refusal to fight and falls silent, signaling his emotional surrender. Sanjaya notes this critical moment, highlighting Arjuna’s inner turmoil and resistance to battle. This verse underscores the depth of his crisis, paving the way for Krishna’s guidance.

shloka:
तमुवाच हृषीकेशः प्रहसन्निव भारत |
सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये विषीदन्तमिदं वचः ||२-१०||
meaning_english: 2.10 To him who was despondent in the midst of the two armies, Krishna, as if smiling, O Bharata, spoke these words.
explanation: Krishna, with a calm and possibly smiling demeanor, begins to address Arjuna’s despondency amidst the armies. This verse marks the start of Krishna’s profound teachings, reflecting his compassionate approach to guiding Arjuna. It highlights the divine reassurance offered in moments of despair.

shloka:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |
अशोच्यानन्वशोचस्त्वं प्रज्ञावादांश्च भाषसे |
गतासूनगतासूंश्च नानुशोचन्ति पण्डिताः ||२-११||
meaning_english: 2.11 The Blessed Lord said  Thou hast grieved for those that should not be grieved for, yet thou speakest words of wisdom. The wise grieve neither for the living nor for the dead.
explanation: Krishna begins his philosophical discourse by pointing out that Arjuna’s grief for those who may die is misplaced, as the wise do not mourn for either the living or the dead. He highlights the eternal nature of the soul, suggesting that true wisdom transcends attachment to temporary existence. This verse introduces the concept of detachment central to Sankhya philosophy.

shloka:
न त्वेवाहं जातु नासं न त्वं नेमे जनाधिपाः |
न चैव न भविष्यामः सर्वे वयमतः परम् ||२-१२||
meaning_english: 2.12 Nor at any time indeed was I not, nor thou, nor these rulers of men, nor verily shall we ever cease to be hereafter.
explanation: Krishna emphasizes the eternal existence of the soul, stating that neither he, Arjuna, nor the kings have ever ceased to exist, nor will they in the future. This verse underscores the timeless nature of the self, transcending birth and death. It lays the foundation for understanding the soul’s permanence in Sankhya philosophy.

shloka:
देहिनोऽस्मिन्यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा |
तथा देहान्तरप्राप्तिर्धीरस्तत्र न मुह्यति ||२-१३||
meaning_english: 2.13 Just as in this body the embodied (soul) passes into childhood, youth and old age, so also does it pass into another body; the firm man does not grieve thereat.
explanation: Krishna explains that just as the soul transitions through stages of life within one body, it moves to another body after death, a process the wise accept without grief. This verse introduces the concept of reincarnation, emphasizing the soul’s continuity. It encourages Arjuna to remain steadfast and unattached to the physical body.

shloka:
मात्रास्पर्शास्तु कौन्तेय शीतोष्णसुखदुःखदाः |
आगमापायिनोऽनित्यास्तांस्तितिक्षस्व भारत ||२-१४||
meaning_english: 2.14 The contacts of the senses with the objects, O son of Kunti, which cause heat and cold, pleasure and pain, have a beginning and an end; they are impermanent; endure them bravely, O Arjuna.
explanation: Krishna teaches that sensory experiences like pleasure and pain are temporary, arising from the interaction of senses with objects, and urges Arjuna to endure them. This verse highlights the fleeting nature of worldly experiences, advocating for mental resilience. It reinforces the need for detachment from transient phenomena.

shloka:
यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ |
समदुःखसुखं धीरं सोऽमृतत्वाय कल्पते ||२-१५||
meaning_english: 2.15 That firm man whom, surely, these afflict not, O chief among men, to whom pleasure and pain are the same, is fit for attaining immortality.
explanation: Krishna declares that a person who remains undisturbed by pleasure or pain, maintaining equanimity, is eligible for liberation. This verse emphasizes the importance of inner stability in achieving spiritual immortality. It encourages Arjuna to cultivate a balanced mind to transcend worldly dualities.

shloka:
नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः |
उभयोरपि दृष्टोऽन्तस्त्वनयोस्तत्त्वदर्शिभिः ||२-१६||
meaning_english: 2.16 The unreal hath no being; there is non-being of the real; the truth about both has been seen by the knowers of the Truth (or the seers of the Essence).
explanation: Krishna explains that the unreal (temporary) has no lasting existence, while the real (eternal) never ceases to be, a truth realized by seers. This verse distinguishes between the transient material world and the eternal soul. It encourages Arjuna to focus on the eternal reality rather than fleeting appearances.

shloka:
अविनाशि तु तद्विद्धि येन सर्वमिदं ततम् |
विनाशमव्ययस्यास्य न कश्चित्कर्तुमर्हति ||२-१७||
meaning_english: 2.17 Know that to be indestructible, by Which all this is pervaded. None can cause the destruction of That, the Imperishable.
explanation: Krishna teaches that the soul, which pervades all existence, is indestructible and cannot be destroyed by any means. This verse reinforces the eternal nature of the self, urging Arjuna to recognize its divine essence. It provides a philosophical basis for overcoming fear of death.

shloka:
अन्तवन्त इमे देहा नित्यस्योक्ताः शरीरिणः |
अनाशिनोऽप्रमेयस्य तस्माद्युध्यस्व भारत ||२-१८||
meaning_english: 2.18 These bodies of the embodied Self, Which is eternal, indestructible and immeasurable, are said to have an end. Therefore fight, O Arjuna.
explanation: Krishna contrasts the temporary nature of physical bodies with the eternal, indestructible soul, urging Arjuna to fight as the body is perishable. This verse emphasizes that the soul’s immortality negates the fear of death in battle. It aligns spiritual truth with the call to fulfill one’s duty.

shloka:
य एनं वेत्ति हन्तारं यश्चैनं मन्यते हतम् |
उभौ तौ न विजानीतो नायं हन्ति न हन्यते ||२-१९||
meaning_english: 2.19 He who takes the Self to be the slayer and he who thinks It is slain, neither of them knows. It slays not, nor is It slain.
explanation: Krishna clarifies that the soul neither kills nor is killed, and those who believe otherwise are ignorant of its true nature. This verse dispels misconceptions about death, emphasizing the soul’s inviolability. It encourages Arjuna to act without fear of causing or suffering harm to the eternal self.

shloka:
न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचिन्
नायं भूत्वा भविता वा न भूयः |
अजो नित्यः शाश्वतोऽयं पुराणो
न हन्यते हन्यमाने शरीरे ||२-२०||
meaning_english: 2.20 It is not born, nor does It ever die; after having been, It again ceases not to be; unborn, eternal, changeless and ancient, It is not killed when the body is killed.
explanation: Krishna describes the soul as unborn, eternal, changeless, and ancient, unaffected by the death of the physical body. This verse reinforces the soul’s immortality, providing Arjuna with a profound reason to overcome his fear of killing in battle. It encapsulates the core Sankhya teaching of the soul’s permanence.

shloka:
वेदाविनाशिनं नित्यं य एनमजमव्ययम् |
कथं स पुरुषः पार्थ कं घातयति हन्ति कम् ||२-२१||
meaning_english: 2.21 Whosoever knows It to be indestructible, eternal, unborn and inexhaustible, how can that man slay, O Arjuna, or cause to be slain?
explanation: Krishna explains that one who truly understands the soul’s eternal and indestructible nature cannot be considered a slayer, as the soul remains unaffected by physical actions. This verse alleviates Arjuna’s fear of killing by emphasizing the soul’s inviolability. It encourages action aligned with spiritual wisdom, free from moral guilt.

shloka:
वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय
नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि |
तथा शरीराणि विहाय जीर्णा-
न्यन्यानि संयाति नवानि देही ||२-२२||
meaning_english: 2.22 Just as a man casts off worn-out clothes and puts on new ones, so also the embodied Self casts off worn-out bodies and enters others which are new.
explanation: Krishna likens the soul’s transition between bodies to changing worn-out clothes, illustrating the process of reincarnation. This metaphor highlights the soul’s continuity beyond physical death, urging Arjuna to detach from the temporary body. It reinforces the idea that death is merely a transition, not an end.

shloka:
नैनं छिन्दन्ति शस्त्राणि नैनं दहति पावकः |
न चैनं क्लेदयन्त्यापो न शोषयति मारुतः ||२-२३||
meaning_english: 2.23 Weapons cut It not, fire burns It not, water wets It not, wind dries It not.
explanation: Krishna describes the soul as impervious to physical elements, emphasizing its indestructible nature against weapons, fire, water, and wind. This verse reassures Arjuna that the soul cannot be harmed, reducing his fear of causing death. It underscores the divine and eternal essence of the self.

shloka:
अच्छेद्योऽयमदाह्योऽयमक्लेद्योऽशोष्य एव च |
नित्यः सर्वगतः स्थाणुरचलोऽयं सनातनः ||२-२४||
meaning_english: 2.24 This Self cannot be cut, burnt, wetted, nor dried up. It is eternal, all-pervading, stable, immovable and ancient.
explanation: Krishna elaborates on the soul’s inviolable qualities, describing it as eternal, all-pervading, and unchangeable, unaffected by physical destruction. This verse reinforces the soul’s divine stability, encouraging Arjuna to focus on its permanence rather than the body’s transience. It provides a foundation for fearless action.

shloka:
अव्यक्तोऽयमचिन्त्योऽयमविकार्योऽयमुच्यते |
तस्मादेवं विदित्वैनं नानुशोचितुमर्हसि ||२-२५||
meaning_english: 2.25 This (Self) is said to be unmanifested, unthinkable and unchangeable. Therefore, knowing This to be such, thou shouldst not grieve.
explanation: Krishna describes the soul as beyond perception, thought, and change, urging Arjuna to cease grieving by understanding its eternal nature. This verse emphasizes the soul’s abstract essence, inaccessible to ordinary senses. It encourages Arjuna to align his perspective with this spiritual truth.

shloka:
अथ चैनं नित्यजातं नित्यं वा मन्यसे मृतम् |
तथापि त्वं महाबाहो नैवं शोचितुमर्हसि ||२-२६||
meaning_english: 2.26 But even if thou thinkest of It as being constantly born and constantly dying, even then, O mighty-armed, thou shouldst not grieve.
explanation: Krishna suggests that even if Arjuna views the soul as subject to constant birth and death, grief is unnecessary, as this cycle is natural. This verse offers a practical perspective to ease Arjuna’s sorrow, accommodating a materialistic view. It encourages resilience in the face of life’s transitions.

shloka:
जातस्य हि ध्रुवो मृत्युर्ध्रुवं जन्म मृतस्य च |
तस्मादपरिहार्येऽर्थे न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि ||२-२७||
meaning_english: 2.27 For certain is death for the born, and certain is birth for the dead; therefore, over the inevitable thou shouldst not grieve.
explanation: Krishna highlights the inevitability of death following birth and birth following death, urging Arjuna not to grieve over this natural cycle. This verse promotes acceptance of life’s unavoidable processes, fostering detachment. It provides a rational basis for Arjuna to overcome his sorrow.

shloka:
अव्यक्तादीनि भूतानि व्यक्तमध्यानि भारत |
अव्यक्तनिधनान्येव तत्र का परिदेवना ||२-२८||
meaning_english: 2.28 Beings are unmanifested in their beginning, manifested in their middle state, O Arjuna, and unmanifested again in their end. What is there to grieve about?
explanation: Krishna explains that all beings originate and return to an unmanifest state, with only a temporary manifested phase, rendering grief pointless. This verse emphasizes the transient nature of existence, encouraging Arjuna to view life and death as fleeting. It promotes a detached perspective on worldly phenomena.

shloka:
आश्चर्यवत्पश्यति कश्चिदेन-
माश्चर्यवद्वदति तथैव चान्यः |
आश्चर्यवच्चैनमन्यः शृणोति
श्रुत्वाप्येनं वेद न चैव कश्चित् ||२-२९||
meaning_english: 2.29 One sees This (the Self) as a wonder; another speaks of It as a wonder; another hears of It as a wonder; yet having heard, none understands It at all.
explanation: Krishna describes the soul as a profound mystery, perceived or spoken of as wondrous but rarely understood, even by those who hear of it. This verse highlights the elusive nature of spiritual truth, beyond ordinary comprehension. It underscores the challenge of grasping the soul’s divine essence.

shloka:
देही नित्यमवध्योऽयं देहे सर्वस्य भारत |
तस्मात्सर्वाणि भूतानि न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि ||२-३०||
meaning_english: 2.30 This, the Indweller in the body of everyone, is ever indestructible, O Arjuna; therefore, thou shouldst not grieve for any creature.
explanation: Krishna reaffirms that the soul, present in all beings, is indestructible, urging Arjuna not to grieve for anyone’s death. This verse emphasizes the universal and eternal nature of the self, transcending individual loss. It encourages Arjuna to act without sorrow, rooted in spiritual truth.

shloka:
स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि |
धर्म्याद्धि युद्धाच्छ्रेयोऽन्यत्क्षत्रियस्य न विद्यते ||२-३१||
meaning_english: 2.31 Further, having regard to thy duty, shouldst not waver, for there is nothing higher for a Kshatriya than a righteous war.
explanation: Krishna shifts to KarmaYoga, urging Arjuna to fulfill his Kshatriya duty by fighting a righteous war without hesitation. This verse emphasizes that such a war is the highest calling for a warrior, aligning with dharma. It encourages Arjuna to embrace his role with resolve.

shloka:
यदृच्छया चोपपन्नं स्वर्गद्वारमपावृतम् |
सुखिनः क्षत्रियाः पार्थ लभन्ते युद्धमीदृशम् ||२-३२||
meaning_english: 2.32 Happy are the Kshatriyas, O Arjuna! who are called upon to fight in such a battle that comes of itself as an open door to heaven.
explanation: Krishna describes the rare opportunity of a righteous battle as a gateway to heaven for Kshatriyas, portraying it as a fortunate duty. This verse motivates Arjuna by framing the war as a divinely ordained chance for spiritual and worldly glory. It emphasizes the honor in fulfilling one’s role.

shloka:
अथ चेत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं संग्रामं न करिष्यसि |
ततः स्वधर्मं कीर्तिं च हित्वा पापमवाप्स्यसि ||२-३३||
meaning_english: 2.33 But if thou wilt not fight this righteous war, then having abandoned thine own duty and fame, thou shalt incur sin.
explanation: Krishna warns Arjuna that refusing to fight this righteous war would mean abandoning his duty and reputation, leading to sin. This verse underscores the consequences of neglecting dharma, emphasizing the importance of action. It urges Arjuna to uphold his Kshatriya responsibilities to avoid spiritual downfall.

shloka:
अकीर्तिं चापि भूतानि कथयिष्यन्ति तेऽव्ययाम् |
सम्भावितस्य चाकीर्तिर्मरणादतिरिच्यते ||२-३४||
meaning_english: 2.34 People, too, will recount thy everlasting dishonour; and to one who has been honoured, dishonour is worse than death.
explanation: Krishna cautions Arjuna that abandoning the battle will lead to lasting dishonor, which is worse than death for a respected warrior. This verse highlights the societal and personal consequences of failing to uphold duty. It motivates Arjuna to act to preserve his honor and legacy.

shloka:
भयाद्रणादुपरतं मंस्यन्ते त्वां महारथाः |
येषां च त्वं बहुमतो भूत्वा यास्यसि लाघवम् ||२-३५||
meaning_english: 2.35 The great car-warriors will think that thou hast withdrawn from the battle through fear; and thou wilt be lightly held by them who have thought much of thee.
explanation: Krishna warns that great warriors will perceive Arjuna’s withdrawal as an act of cowardice, diminishing his esteemed reputation. This verse emphasizes the social stigma of abandoning duty, urging Arjuna to fight to maintain his honor. It reinforces the importance of courage in fulfilling one’s role.

shloka:
अवाच्यवादांश्च बहून्वदिष्यन्ति तवाहिताः |
निन्दन्तस्तव सामर्थ्यं ततो दुःखतरं नु किम् ||२-३६||
meaning_english: 2.36 Thy enemies also, cavilling at thy power, will speak many abusive words. What is more painful than this?
explanation: Krishna warns Arjuna that his enemies will mock his strength with harsh words if he avoids battle, causing greater pain than fighting. This verse highlights the social consequences of abandoning duty, emphasizing the sting of public criticism. It motivates Arjuna to uphold his warrior’s honor by facing the challenge.

shloka:
हतो वा प्राप्स्यसि स्वर्गं जित्वा वा भोक्ष्यसे महीम् |
तस्मादुत्तिष्ठ कौन्तेय युद्धाय कृतनिश्चयः ||२-३७||
meaning_english: 2.37 Slain, thou wilt obtain heaven; victorious, thou wilt enjoy the earth; therefore, stand up, O son of Kunti, resolved to fight.
explanation: Krishna encourages Arjuna to fight by presenting a win-win scenario: death in battle leads to heaven, while victory brings earthly rule. This verse emphasizes the spiritual and material rewards of fulfilling one’s duty. It urges Arjuna to rise with determination, free from hesitation.

shloka:
सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ |
ततो युद्धाय युज्यस्व नैवं पापमवाप्स्यसि ||२-३८||
meaning_english: 2.38 Having made pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat the same, engage thou in battle for the sake of battle; thus thou shalt not incur sin.
explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to treat opposites like pleasure and pain or victory and defeat with equanimity, focusing solely on the act of fighting as duty. This verse introduces the principle of detached action, ensuring no sin is incurred. It emphasizes performing one’s role without attachment to outcomes.

shloka:
एषा तेऽभिहिता साङ्ख्ये बुद्धिर्योगे त्विमां शृणु |
बुद्ध्या युक्तो यया पार्थ कर्मबन्धं प्रहास्यसि ||२-३९||
meaning_english: 2.39 This, which has been taught to thee, is wisdon concerning Sankhya. Now listen to wisdom concerning Yoga, endowed with which, O Arjuna, thou shalt cast off the bonds of action.
explanation: Krishna transitions from Sankhya’s philosophical wisdom to KarmaYoga’s practical approach, promising Arjuna freedom from the bondage of actions. This verse marks a shift to teaching disciplined action, which liberates one from karmic consequences. It sets the stage for understanding selfless action as a path to liberation.

shloka:
नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते |
स्वल्पमप्यस्य धर्मस्य त्रायते महतो भयात् ||२-४०||
meaning_english: 2.40 In this there is no loss of effort, nor is there any harm (production of contrary results or transgression). Even a little of this knowledge (even a little practice of this Yoga) protects one from great fear.
explanation: Krishna assures Arjuna that practicing KarmaYoga incurs no loss of effort or negative consequences, and even minimal practice offers significant protection from fear. This verse highlights the safety and efficacy of disciplined action. It encourages Arjuna to begin the path of Yoga with confidence.

shloka:
व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन |
बहुशाखा ह्यनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम् ||२-४१||
meaning_english: 2.41 Here, O joy of the Kurus, there is but a single one-pointed determination; many-branched and endless are the thoughts of the irresolute.
explanation: Krishna contrasts the focused, single-minded resolve of a disciplined mind with the scattered, endless thoughts of the irresolute. This verse emphasizes the importance of clarity and determination in pursuing KarmaYoga. It urges Arjuna to cultivate a resolute mind for spiritual progress.

shloka:
यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्यविपश्चितः |
वेदवादरताः पार्थ नान्यदस्तीति वादिनः ||२-४२||
meaning_english: 2.42 Flowery speech is uttered by the unwise, taking pleasure in the eulogising words of the Vedas, O Arjuna, saying, "There is nothing else."
explanation: Krishna critiques those who, lacking true wisdom, cling to the Vedas’ flowery promises of material rewards, believing nothing else matters. This verse highlights the folly of pursuing temporary gains over spiritual truth. It urges Arjuna to seek deeper understanding beyond superficial teachings.

shloka:
कामात्मानः स्वर्गपरा जन्मकर्मफलप्रदाम् |
क्रियाविशेषबहुलां भोगैश्वर्यगतिं प्रति ||२-४३||
meaning_english: 2.43 Full of desires, having heaven as their goal, (they utter speech which is directed to ends) leading to new births as the result of their works, and prescribe various methods abounding in specific actions, for the attainment of pleasure and power.
explanation: Krishna describes those driven by desires who seek heavenly rewards through Vedic rituals, resulting in endless cycles of rebirth. This verse critiques attachment to pleasure and power, which binds one to karma. It encourages Arjuna to pursue selfless action over desire-driven rituals.

shloka:
भोगैश्वर्यप्रसक्तानां तयापहृतचेतसाम् |
व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिः समाधौ न विधीयते ||२-४४||
meaning_english: 2.44 For those who are attached to pleasure and power, whose minds are drawn away by such teaching, that determinate reason is not formed which is steadily bent on meditation and Samadhi (superconscious state).
explanation: Krishna explains that those obsessed with pleasure and power, swayed by materialistic teachings, cannot develop the focused mind needed for meditation and spiritual liberation. This verse underscores the obstacle of attachment to worldly gains. It urges Arjuna to cultivate a disciplined, meditative focus.

shloka:
त्रैगुण्यविषया वेदा निस्त्रैगुण्यो भवार्जुन |
निर्द्वन्द्वो नित्यसत्त्वस्थो निर्योगक्षेम आत्मवान् ||२-४५||
meaning_english: 2.45 The Vedas deal with the three attributes (of Nature); be thou above these three attributes. O Arjuna, free yourself from the pairs of opposites, and ever remain in the ality of Sattva (goodness), freed from (the thought of) acisition and preservation, and be established in the Self.
explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to rise above the three gunas (qualities of nature) described in the Vedas, embracing Sattva, transcending dualities, and focusing on the Self without concern for gain or loss. This verse promotes a state of inner purity and detachment. It guides Arjuna toward spiritual liberation through self-realization.

shloka:
यावानर्थ उदपाने सर्वतः सम्प्लुतोदके |
तावान्सर्वेषु वेदेषु ब्राह्मणस्य विजानतः ||२-४६||
meaning_english: 2.46 To the Brahmana who has known the Self, all the Vedas are of as much use as is a reservoir of water in a place where there is a flood.
explanation: Krishna compares the Vedas’ utility to a small reservoir in a flooded area, suggesting that for one who has realized the Self, their guidance is redundant. This verse emphasizes that true wisdom surpasses scriptural knowledge, focusing on direct experience of the Self. It encourages Arjuna to seek inner realization over external texts.

shloka:
कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन |
मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि ||२-४७||
meaning_english: 2.47 Thy right is to work only, but never with its fruits; let not the fruits of action be thy motive, nor let thy attachment be to inaction.
explanation: Krishna teaches Arjuna to perform actions without attachment to their outcomes, emphasizing that one’s duty is to act, not to chase results. This verse introduces the core principle of KarmaYoga, advocating selfless action while discouraging both desire for rewards and avoidance of work. It guides Arjuna toward disciplined, unattached effort.

shloka:
योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय |
सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते ||२-४८||
meaning_english: 2.48 Perform action, O Arjuna, being steadfast in Yoga, abandoning attachment and balanced in success and failure. Evenness of mind is called Yoga.
explanation: Krishna urges Arjuna to act with a steady mind, free from attachment, and to remain balanced in success or failure, defining this equanimity as Yoga. This verse emphasizes performing duties with mental stability, unaffected by outcomes. It highlights the essence of KarmaYoga as evenness in action.

shloka:
दूरेण ह्यवरं कर्म बुद्धियोगाद्धनञ्जय |
बुद्धौ शरणमन्विच्छ कृपणाः फलहेतवः ||२-४९||
meaning_english: 2.49 Far lower than the Yoga of wisdon is action, O Arjuna. Seek thou refuge in wisdom; wretched are they whose motive is the fruit.
explanation: Krishna contrasts action driven by desire for results with the superior path of wise, detached action, urging Arjuna to seek refuge in wisdom. This verse critiques those motivated by selfish gains, calling them wretched. It emphasizes the liberating power of selfless action guided by understanding.

shloka:
बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते |
तस्माद्योगाय युज्यस्व योगः कर्मसु कौशलम् ||२-५०||
meaning_english: 2.50 Endowed with wisdom (evenness of mind), one casts off in this life both good and evil deeds; therefore, devote thyself to Yoga; Yoga is skill in action.
explanation: Krishna explains that a wise person, practicing Yoga, transcends both good and bad karma through balanced action, describing Yoga as skillful performance of duties. This verse highlights KarmaYoga’s ability to free one from karmic bonds. It encourages Arjuna to master action through disciplined wisdom.

shloka:
कर्मजं बुद्धियुक्ता हि फलं त्यक्त्वा मनीषिणः |
जन्मबन्धविनिर्मुक्ताः पदं गच्छन्त्यनामयम् ||२-५१||
meaning_english: 2.51 The wise, possessed of knowledge, having abandoned the fruits of their actions, and being freed from the fetters of birth, go to the place which is beyond all evil.
explanation: Krishna states that wise individuals, by renouncing the fruits of actions, escape the cycle of birth and death, attaining a state free from suffering. This verse underscores the liberating outcome of selfless action in KarmaYoga. It motivates Arjuna to pursue this path for ultimate freedom.

shloka:
यदा ते मोहकलिलं बुद्धिर्व्यतितरिष्यति |
तदा गन्तासि निर्वेदं श्रोतव्यस्य श्रुतस्य च ||२-५२||
meaning_english: 2.52 When thy intellect crosses beyond the mire of delusion, then thou shalt attain to indifference as to what has been heard and what has yet to be heard.
explanation: Krishna promises that when Arjuna’s intellect overcomes delusion, he will become indifferent to external knowledge, both past and future. This verse highlights the clarity gained through spiritual wisdom, transcending reliance on scriptures. It encourages Arjuna to seek inner understanding for liberation.

shloka:
श्रुतिविप्रतिपन्ना ते यदा स्थास्यति निश्चला |
समाधावचला बुद्धिस्तदा योगमवाप्स्यसि ||२-५३||
meaning_english: 2.53 When thy intellect, which is perplexed by the Veda text, which thou hast read, shall stand immovable and steady in the Self, then thou shalt attain Self-realisation.
explanation: Krishna explains that when Arjuna’s intellect, once confused by Vedic texts, becomes steady and focused on the Self, he will achieve Self-realization. This verse emphasizes the importance of unwavering focus in meditation for spiritual awakening. It guides Arjuna toward inner stability and ultimate Yoga.

shloka:
अर्जुन उवाच |
स्थितप्रज्ञस्य का भाषा समाधिस्थस्य केशव |
स्थितधीः किं प्रभाषेत किमासीत व्रजेत किम् ||२-५४||
meaning_english: 2.54 Arjuna said  What, O Krishna, is the description of him who has steady wisdom, and is merged in the superconscious state? How does one of steady wisdom speak, how does he sit, how does he walk?
explanation: Arjuna, intrigued by Krishna’s teachings, asks how a person of steady wisdom, immersed in a superconscious state, behaves and appears in daily life. This verse reflects Arjuna’s curiosity about the practical manifestations of enlightenment. It sets the stage for Krishna’s description of a realized soul.

shloka:
श्रीभगवानुवाच |
प्रजहाति यदा कामान्सर्वान्पार्थ मनोगतान् |
आत्मन्येवात्मना तुष्टः स्थितप्रज्ञस्तदोच्यते ||२-५५||
meaning_english: 2.55 The Blessed Lord said  When a man completely casts off, O Arjuna, all the desires of the mind and is satisfied in the Self by the Self, then is he said to be one of steady wisdom.
explanation: Krishna describes a person of steady wisdom as one who has abandoned all mental desires and finds complete satisfaction within the Self. This verse defines the hallmark of enlightenment as inner contentment, free from external cravings. It offers Arjuna a model for spiritual attainment through detachment.

shloka:
दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमनाः सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः |
वीतरागभयक्रोधः स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते ||२-५६||
meaning_english: 2.56 He whose mind is not shaken by adversity, who does not hanker after pleasures, and is free from attachment, fear and anger, is called a sage of steady wisdom.
explanation: Krishna describes a sage of steady wisdom as one who remains unshaken by adversity, unattached to pleasures, and free from emotions like attachment, fear, and anger. This verse outlines the qualities of a spiritually mature individual, emphasizing mental stability. It provides Arjuna with a model for achieving inner calm through detachment.

shloka:
यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम् |
नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ||२-५७||
meaning_english: 2.57 He who is everywhere without attachment, on meeting with anything good or bad, who neither rejoices not hastes, his wisdom is fixed.
explanation: Krishna explains that a person with fixed wisdom remains unattached, neither rejoicing in favorable outcomes nor resenting unfavorable ones. This verse emphasizes maintaining equanimity in all circumstances, free from emotional bias. It guides Arjuna toward a balanced perspective, essential for spiritual growth.

shloka:
यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः |
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ||२-५८||
meaning_english: 2.58 When, like the tortoise which withdraws on all sides its limbs, he withdraws his senses from the sense-objects, then his wisdom becomes steady.
explanation: Krishna uses the analogy of a tortoise retracting its limbs to describe how a wise person withdraws their senses from external objects, achieving steady wisdom. This verse highlights the importance of sense control for mental stability. It encourages Arjuna to practice disciplined detachment from sensory distractions.

shloka:
विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिनः |
रसवर्जं रसोऽप्यस्य परं दृष्ट्वा निवर्तते ||२-५९||
meaning_english: 2.59 The objects of the senses turn away from the abstinent man leaving the longing (behind); but his longing also turns away on seeing the Supreme.
explanation: Krishna explains that while abstinence may stop sensory indulgence, true detachment occurs only when one experiences the Supreme, eliminating all longing. This verse underscores the transformative power of divine realization over mere restraint. It motivates Arjuna to seek the higher truth to transcend sensory desires.

shloka:
यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चितः |
इन्द्रियाणि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसभं मनः ||२-६०||
meaning_english: 2.60 The turbulent senses, O Arjuna, do violently carry away the mind of a wise man though he be striving (to control them).
explanation: Krishna warns that even a wise person striving for control can have their mind disrupted by powerful senses, highlighting the challenge of mastery. This verse acknowledges the difficulty of restraining sensory impulses. It encourages Arjuna to remain vigilant in his efforts toward self-discipline.

shloka:
तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्परः |
वशे हि यस्येन्द्रियाणि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ||२-६१||
meaning_english: 2.61 Having restrained them all he should sit steadfast, intent on Me; his wisdom is steady whose senses are under control.
explanation: Krishna advises Arjuna to restrain all senses and focus steadfastly on the Divine, stating that true wisdom is achieved when senses are fully controlled. This verse emphasizes disciplined focus on a higher spiritual goal. It guides Arjuna toward achieving stability through devotion and self-mastery.

shloka:
ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते |
सङ्गात्सञ्जायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते ||२-६२||
meaning_english: 2.62 When a man thinks of the objects, attachment for them arises; from attachment desire is born; from desire anger arises.
explanation: Krishna outlines the chain of downfall, where contemplating sensory objects leads to attachment, then desire, and ultimately anger when desires are unfulfilled. This verse illustrates the dangers of unchecked thoughts. It warns Arjuna to guard his mind against sensory entanglement.

shloka:
क्रोधाद्भवति सम्मोहः सम्मोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः |
स्मृतिभ्रंशाद् बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति ||२-६३||
meaning_english: 2.63 From anger comes delusion; from delusion loss of memory; from loss of memory the destruction of discrimination; from the destruction of discrimination he perishes.
explanation: Krishna continues the chain of downfall, explaining how anger leads to delusion, memory loss, destruction of discrimination, and ultimately spiritual ruin. This verse highlights the catastrophic consequences of uncontrolled emotions. It urges Arjuna to maintain mental clarity to avoid self-destruction.

shloka:
रागद्वेषविमुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन् | (or वियुक्तैस्तु)
आत्मवश्यैर्विधेयात्मा प्रसादमधिगच्छति ||२-६४||
meaning_english: 2.64 But the self-controlled man, moving among the objects with the senses under restraint and free from attraction and repulsion, attains to peace.
explanation: Krishna describes how a self-controlled person, free from attraction and aversion, achieves peace by navigating sensory objects with restrained senses. This verse contrasts the downfall of uncontrolled senses with the serenity of discipline. It encourages Arjuna to cultivate mastery for inner tranquility.

shloka:
प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते |
प्रसन्नचेतसो ह्याशु बुद्धिः पर्यवतिष्ठते ||२-६५||
meaning_english: 2.65 In that peace all pains are destroyed; for the intellect of the tranil-minded soon becomes steady.
explanation: Krishna explains that achieving inner peace eliminates all suffering, and a tranquil mind quickly attains a steady intellect. This verse highlights the transformative power of peace in stabilizing one’s wisdom. It motivates Arjuna to seek tranquility through disciplined practice for spiritual clarity.

shloka:
नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना |
न चाभावयतः शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुतः सुखम् ||२-६६||
meaning_english: 2.66 There is no knowledge of the Self to the unsteady and to the unsteady no meditation is possible, and to the unmeditative there can be no peace, and to the man who has no peace, how can there be happiness?
explanation: Krishna explains that an unsteady mind cannot attain Self-knowledge or meditate, leading to a lack of peace and happiness. This verse underscores the interconnectedness of mental discipline, meditation, and inner tranquility. It urges Arjuna to cultivate steadiness to achieve spiritual fulfillment.

shloka:
इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते |
तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि ||२-६७||
meaning_english: 2.67 For the mind, which follows in the wake of the wandering senses, carries away his discrimination, as the wind (carries away) a boat on the waters.
explanation: Krishna compares an uncontrolled mind, swayed by wandering senses, to a boat drifted by wind, losing its discrimination. This verse highlights the danger of sensory indulgence in disrupting wisdom. It encourages Arjuna to restrain his senses to maintain clarity and focus.

shloka:
तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः |
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ||२-६८||
meaning_english: 2.68 Therefore, O mighty-armed Arjuna, his knowledge is steady whose senses are completely restrained from sense-objects.
explanation: Krishna emphasizes that steady wisdom is achieved by fully restraining the senses from their objects, ensuring mental stability. This verse reinforces the importance of sense control for spiritual progress. It motivates Arjuna to practice discipline to attain unwavering knowledge.

shloka:
या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी |
यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः ||२-६९||
meaning_english: 2.69 That which is night to all beings, in that the self-controlled man is awake; when all beings are awake, that is night for the Muni (sage) who sees.
explanation: Krishna contrasts the sage’s spiritual awareness with ordinary perception, noting that a self-controlled sage is awake to divine truth while others are immersed in worldly pursuits, which are like night to the enlightened. This verse highlights the sage’s transcendent perspective. It inspires Arjuna to seek spiritual awakening.

shloka:
आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं
समुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत् |
तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे
स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी ||२-७०||
meaning_english: 2.70 He attains peace into whom all desires enter as waters enter the ocean which, filled from all sides, remains unmoved; but not the man who is full of desires.
explanation: Krishna likens a peaceful person to an ocean, unmoved despite desires entering like rivers, contrasting this with one consumed by desires. This verse illustrates the serenity of detachment, unaffected by external influences. It encourages Arjuna to remain steady amid desires for true peace.

shloka:
विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः |
निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः स शान्तिमधिगच्छति ||२-७१||
meaning_english: 2.71 That man attains peace who, abandoning all desires, moves about without longing, without the sense of mine and without egoism.
explanation: Krishna describes true peace as attained by one who relinquishes desires, possessiveness, and ego, living free from longing. This verse emphasizes the liberation found in complete detachment and selflessness. It guides Arjuna toward a state of inner tranquility through renunciation of personal motives.

shloka:
एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति |
स्थित्वास्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति ||२-७२||
meaning_english: 2.72 This is the Brahmic seat (eternal state), O son of Pritha. Attaining to this, none is deluded. Being established therein, even at the end of life, one attains to oneness with Brahman.
explanation: Krishna describes the eternal state of Brahman, where one attains freedom from delusion and, even at life’s end, achieves oneness with the Divine. This verse encapsulates the ultimate goal of KarmaYoga—union with Brahman. It inspires Arjuna to strive for this enlightened state through disciplined practice.
